bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Wallach to J. F. Siler, August 28, 1950

div1.p: Wallach describes plans for a national and possibly international Walter Reed commemorative publicity campaign under the auspices of the Reed Memorial Association, and stresses the importance of the campaign in light of communism.

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Wallach to J. F. Siler, August 28, 1950
div1.opener:
28 August 1950
Colonel J. F. Siler
1835 Eye Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler,
div1.p:
Earlier this year, I had the pleasure of meeting you when I brought to your
attention our proposal for a commemorative program for Dr. Walter Reed, par-
ticularly on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of the Walter Reed
Commission and on the anniversaries of Dr. Reed's birth and death.

As you will recall, I showed you at that time a joint congressional resolu-
tion. Unfortunately, one of the sponsors, Representative Bland, died shortly
thereafter with the result that the project was abandoned.

I believe, however, that a national and perhaps world-wide program of obser-
vance can be more useful than ever before. The communist boasts must be
challenged and met by the record of American, and in this case, U. S. Army
achievement.

I believe, too, that our agency can work out a program for, and under the
auspices of, the Walter Reed Association; and that the financing can be ob-
tained.

I wonder whether it would be possible for me to meet formally with the au-
thorized officers of your Association in order to arrive at a suitable un-
derstanding.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Sidney Wallach SW:g
cc: Dr. P. S. Hench
